awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: Using ChatGPT and Machine Learning to Power Positive Change among Justice Involved Youth
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to test the benefits of artificial intelligence (AI) to enhance a platform which aids justice-involved youth to develop protective factors for positive change. The project uses advanced machine learning and large language model technologies to optimize the platform's effectiveness and support this vulnerable group, many of whom have adverse childhood experiences, so that they can break the cycle of re-offending. These enhancements empower youth by creating more relevant growth recommendations offering tailored, strengths-based feedback to break the cycle of recidivism and support the transition into productive societal roles. The platform has commercial potential with opportunities for deployment across 3,143 U.S. counties, which collectively serve 800,000 justice-involved youth annually. Successful implementation may alter the life trajectories of these youth, such that they can make positive life changes. This transformation would lessen the economic burden on our already stretched penal systems, while unlocking the potential of these youth to contribute positively to society. 

This project integrates state-of-the-art machine learning and large language models to fortify an innovative social growth platform, enabling justice-involved youth to make positive life changes. The platform is underpinned by a research-validated growth cycle, and features a dynamic feed governed by intelligent algorithms, specialized protective factor journeys, and a narrative-centric approach that leverages strength-based, social connectivity. The project will facilitate the refinement of the algorithmic architecture behind the dynamic feed to enhance user engagement, thereby promoting protective factors. Large language models will be integrated to serve as an intelligence-augmented mechanism to bolster the strength-based feedback loop within life integration stories.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

The Journey.do project is a groundbreaking initiative that leverages next-generation technology to support justice-involved youth in making positive life changes as part of their rehabilitation process. This project, funded by the National Science Foundation's Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) program, focused on enhancing the Journey.do platform to create a scalable, impactful, and commercially viable solution that addresses the complex needs of this vulnerable population. Specifically, Phase I focused on integrating and testing generative AI to support personal development, providing actionable and scalable insights to ensure change happens.

Intellectual Merit

The core intellectual contribution of Journey.do lies in its innovative use of generative AI to enhance a comprehensive behavioral change program tailored for justice-involved youth. Our next generation growth platform and behavioral change program integrates AI with therapeutic frameworks and a "come alongside" service model to deliver hyper-personalized care that addresses each individual's unique criminogenic needs and ensures responsive life skills are grown.

The technological advancements achieved during Phase I include the development of an AI-enhanced coaching dashboard, the implementation of a behavioral change framework, the Journey Arc, and the empirical validation of AI's ability to provide scalable, high-quality, and trauma-informed feedback. These enhancements are built on rigorous research and leverage evidence-based practices to ensure youth are not only seen and valued, but supported and held accountable to make positive changes. 

Integrating AI into the platform has significantly enhanced its scalability and effectiveness. The AI's role in generating growth plans, reviewing life stories, and creating transition plans ensures that every youth receives consistent, strength-based support despite human resource limitations. Research found that AI-produced insights were viewed as accurate, trustworthy, and useful by youth, staff, and officers. This approach ensures that justice-involved youth are empowered to make meaningful life changes, reducing the likelihood of recidivism and contributing to their long-term well-being.

Broader Impacts

The broader impact of the Journey.do project is substantial, with the potential to break the cycle of recidivism and transform the lives of justice-involved youth across the United States. By addressing the criminogenic needs of these youth, the platform facilitates their transition into productive members of society, thereby reducing the societal and financial costs associated with re-offending.

Journey.do's platform is designed to be scalable, with the potential for deployment across 3,143 counties that interface with over 750,000 justice-involved youth annually. The successful realization of this platform's capabilities will fundamentally change life outcomes for this vulnerable population, providing the tools and support they need to navigate away from the justice system and toward positive futures.

Moreover, this initiative represents a significant investment in human capital and the long-term well-being of our nation. By providing justice-involved youth with personalized, evidence-based support, Journey.do aims to ensure that they are not only held accountable for their actions but are given the opportunity to grow, learn, and ultimately thrive.

Summary of Outcomes

Throughout the Phase I SBIR project, Journey.do made significant strides in enhancing its platform to better serve justice-involved youth. Key achievements include:  

 1. Development of the Journey Arc: A behavioral change framework that guides youth from intake to outtake, ensuring that every step of their journey is supported by evidence-based practices.

 2. Validation of AI-Insights: Research with youth, staff, and officers confirmed that AI-generated insights were accurate, useful, and accessible, even exceeding the quality of human reviewers with fewer resources. This validation underscores AI's effectiveness in providing scalable, timely, and trauma-informed support that significantly contributes to youths’ personal growth. 

 3. AI-Enhanced Coaching Dashboard: Integration of AI into the coaching process provided consistent, trauma-informed feedback and actionable insights, significantly reducing the burden on overextended staff and allowing us to scale personalized care.

4. Scalability and Commercial Viability: The platform's scalability was demonstrated through empirical testing, with over 1500 youth using the program. Feedback from users and potential buyers has informed further refinements, positioning Journey.do as a commercially viable product ready for broader implementation.

5. Positive Impact on Youth: The integration of AI and the comprehensive nature of the program have been shown to positively impact youth and their outcomes. This is vital considering justice-impacted youth are among society’s most vulnerable yet underserved populations.

Collectively, these outcomes demonstrate the power of generative AI to support personal change, while positioning us to implement at scale so those we serve can make necessary life changes.

Conclusion

The Journey.do Phase I SBIR project has laid a strong foundation for a transformative solution that addresses the needs of justice-involved youth. By leveraging cutting-edge technology, generative AI, and evidence-based practices, the platform not only provides immediate support to these youth but also has the potential to create lasting change on a national scale. With continued support and development, Journey.do is poised to become a leading force in the effort to reform juvenile justice and improve outcomes for at-risk youth across the country.


Last Modified: 09/01/2024
Modified by: Sasha Barab
